descriptionSet.description: A poster, circa 1930s shows Mahatma Gandhi looking at a map of India from a cloud above. We see a large factory in the upper left corner, a man in a western suit running towards a large bag of money, his enlarged hand reaching out for the bag. There is a woman with a spinning wheel, wearing a sari, there is a farmer with a bull on a field, and another farmer holding a tool on his shoulder. The poster is surrounded by a wooden frame.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: TO WHOM WILL YOU GIVE?
text-hi: आप किसको देना चाहते हैं?
text-en: 60 CRORE'S
text-hi: ६० करोड
text-en: To Foreign Mills
text-hi: विदेशी मिलों को
text-en: or
text-hi: या
text-en: To our poor Cultivators?
text-hi: अपने गरीब किसानों को
text-en: Copy Right K

description-en: A poster, circa 1930s shows Mahatma Gandhi looking at a map of India from a cloud above. We see a large factory in the upper left corner, a man in a western suit running towards a large bag of money, his enlarged hand reaching out for the bag. There is a woman with a spinning wheel, wearing a sari, there is a farmer with a bull on a field, and another farmer holding a tool on his shoulder. The poster is surrounded by a wooden frame.

explanatory comments/crosstagging: An outline map of India is occupied by the half-clothed figures of farmers tilling the soil, and a woman seated at a spinning wheel; also placed on the map is a gunny sack with the words “60 crores” inscribed across its front. To the west of the map of India is the partially visible map of England, clearly an industrial country whose output threatens the inhabits of its distant colony, and their wellbeing and livelihood. The Indian viewer of this print is offered a choice: they could either remain slaves “to foreign mills,” or instead—and this is what is clearly implied—become supporters of “our poor cultivators,” whose hard work seems to be sustaining the nation. It is important to note that the producers of this print assume that their viewer will be cartographically literate enough to visually recognize “India” in the form of its geo-body. Gandhi’s presence at the top of the map of course helps in this identification, as does the presence of his trademark spinning wheel. (Sumathi Ramaswamy) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The poster challenges use of of British goods and highlights that India annually looses Rs 60 crore due to imports from Britain,while the local cultivators perish. The poster shows mills on map of Britain and a British industrialist reaching out for Rs 60 crore. Also shown local peasants and a woman at the spinning wheel. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Pinney, in 'Photos of the Gods', discusses the relation of swadeshi politics to the image circulation - his book also carries a proscribed image from 1930s, with a personified rapacious England dressed in Bowler hat with British flag and a suit, standing on 'England' (Inglend in devanagari) - looting starving India, represented by a poor - starving - family seated on the ground of India's map (devanagari bharatvarsh). While the image also shows the words 'COPY RIGHT' ON THE LEFT, it has the artist's name: Devnarayan Varma, is dated with 1931, India Office Library (cb)
related literature: Pinney, Christopher. 2004. Photos of the Gods. Delhi: Oxford University Press
related literature: Guha, Ramachandra, 2008. India after Gandhi (New York: HarperCollins), pp. 51-96. (gs)

related literature: Ramaswamy, Sumathi 2011. "Artful Mapping in Bazaar India. Cartographic Reflections on the Priya Paul Collection", http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/116/index_1.html, last accessed 2011-03-28 (gs)
related literature: Trivedi, Lisa. 2003. Visually Mapping the Nation: Swadeshi Politics in Nationalist India, 1920-1930. Journal of Asian Studies 62 (1): Figure 2. (gs)
